Did you kill out all lateral velocity with the vessel. I haven't actually used the claw on any vessel besides an asteroid but it appears to be more fickle than a docking port when it comes to making contact, but I noticed that killing out lateral velocity seems most important.

The claw has to hit the roid more or less perpendicular to its surface to stick. Because roids have very irregular surfaces, when usually happens is that as the ship comes in perpendicular to the roid's center of mass, the surface there is very sloped so only 1 corner of the claw will touch the roid and it won't grab if you stop the ship at this point. You usually have to rotate the ship to bring the whole face of the claw into contact with the sloping roid surface. This of course throws the ship out of line with the CoM, but that's why you have the pivot. Once grabbed, unlock the pivot, rotate the ship back to line up with the CoM, then lock the pivot.

You have to remember when grabbing an asteroid to "arm" the Claw before touching the asteroid; when it's armed you can see hooks coming out of it, when it's disarmed the hooks are shrouded like they are in the VAB. In order to let go of an asteroid you've grabbed onto, you have to disarm the Claw.

You can arm and disarm the Claw by right-clicking on it and selecting the option in the pop up menu, or you can set an action group key to toggle between armed and disarmed.

-- Steve
You have to be pretty gentle with it. Your target speed at contact should be around 0.1m/s or you'll bounce off or have other problems.
